finglish_example: The brand has attracted lots of positive feedback
corrected: The brand has received lots of positive feedback
sidebar: Things don't 'attract feedback' in English. They 'receive feedback'. 'The new brand has received a lot of positive feedback.'

finglish_example: The event gathered close to 300 attendees
corrected: The event attracted close to 300 attendees
sidebar: Events don't 'gather people'. They 'attract people'. 'The event attracted 300 attendees.' 'The conference attracted 1,000 delegates.'

finglish_example: Keep it lean and manage the projects without heavy resource planning!
corrected: Keep it lean and manage the projects without cumbersome/burdensome/unnecessarily extensive resource planning!
sidebar: Heavy' doesn't go naturally with 'planning' in English. What you probably mean is 'cumbersome planning', 'excessive planning' or 'burdensome planning'.

finglish_example: One of PehuTec’s longest line telecommunications pioneers is electronics designer Jorma Savolainen; Heikki Silvennoinen, a Finnish long-line blues guitarist and singer
corrected: One of PehuTec’s most experienced telecommunications pioneers is electronics designer Jorma Savolainen; Heikki Silvennoinen, a legendary Finnish blues guitarist and singer
sidebar: This is a direct translation of Finnish. We don't say 'long line' or 'longest line' in English. Instead, we say that someone has lots of experience or is experienced. 'He is the most experienced professional in his field.' 'She is an experienced coder.'

finglish_example: Career talk with a low threshold; With Pihlajalinna’s Worry in Mind service, employees can contact the mental health line with a low threshold whenever they are worried about something; With us, you can develop your entrepreneurial skills and ideas with a low threshold
corrected: Career talk open to everyone; With Pihlajalinna’s Worry in Mind service, employees can feel free to contact the mental health line at any time they are worried about something, big or small; With us, you can develop your entrepreneurial skills and ideas with little risk
replacement: at any time | open to everyone | with little risk | accessibly
sidebar: This is a direct translation of Finnish. We don't say 'at a low threshold' in English. We say that services or facilities are 'open to everyone', 'accessible', 'available at any time' or something similar.

finglish_example: There are many of those who log into the systems and move around in premises
corrected: There are many of those who log into the systems and use/enter premises
sidebar: We don't 'move around' in English the same way Finnish talks about 'moving around in'. Instead, we 'use premises', 'exercise' or 'spend time outdoors'.

finglish_example:
Wertti, the end result of the cooperation between HUNT AI and Kodan, is a user-friendly online service that makes it easy for consumers to communicate with insurance companies. It helps consumers submit insurance quote requests effortlessly through a simple and adaptive process, matching their needs with multiple offers from various companies.
On the other hand, the service benefits insurers by providing them with high-quality leads and enabling them to focus on delivering optimal solutions for clients. Insurers no longer have to rely on cold calls, which may also be prohibited soon due to EU regulations.
corrected:
Wertti, the end result of the cooperation between HUNT AI and Kodan, is a user-friendly online service that makes it easy for consumers to communicate with insurance companies. It helps consumers submit insurance quote requests effortlessly through a simple and adaptive process, matching their needs with multiple offers from various companies.
The service also benefits insurers by providing them with high-quality leads and enabling them to focus on delivering optimal solutions for clients. Insurers no longer have to rely on cold calls, which may also be prohibited soon due to EU regulations.
sidebar: The program should search for paragraphs with "on the other hand" which are preceded by paragraphs which do NOT contain "on the one hand".

finglish_example: Let us know what you are interested in and we will contact you soonest possible
corrected: Let us know what you are interested in and we will contact you as soon as possible.
sidebar: The idiom in English is 'as soon as possible', not 'soonest possible'.

finglish_example: Testing the plugs gave immediately a strong reaction: the high level of stress caused by noise started to decrease and the idea of refining the earplugs came into the mind.
corrected: Testing the plugs immediately had a positive effect: the high level of stress caused by noise started to decrease and the idea of refining the earplugs came into the mind.
sidebar: Strong reaction' in English means a negative reaction. Is this what you meant? If not, consider 'positive effect'.

finglish_example: The company takes the system into use
corrected: The company deploys/commissions/launches the system
sidebar: Take into use' is not real English but Finglish. We don't 'take things into use' in English: we launch, commission, deploy, roll out, start using or use.

finglish_example: If the system consists of multiple servers and tens of cameras, then we recommend proper server hardware with client workstations
corrected: If the system consists of multiple servers and dozens of cameras, then we recommend proper server hardware with client workstations
sidebar: In English, we talk about 'dozens' of things, not 'tens'.

finglish_example: You want results. That’s given.
corrected: You want results. That’s a given.
sidebar: The phrase in English is 'that's a given'.

finglish_example: Founded in the turn of the millennium in Finland, we at Barona have
corrected: Here at Barona, which was founded in Finland at the turn of the millennium, we
sidebar: Instead of 'we at (company)', write 'at (company), we…' Or rewrite the sentence entirely to begin with 'our team', 'our company', etc.

finglish_example: Goal-driven, systematic development of supervisors’ managerial skills and the functions of work communities enables employees’ occupational wellbeing and the success of business operations.
corrected: Goal-driven, systematic development of supervisors’ managerial skills and the functions of workplaces/teams enables employees’ occupational wellbeing and the success of business operations.
sidebar: We don't usually say 'work community' in English. It's not a phrase English-speakers are familiar with. Say 'workplace', 'team' or something else instead.
notes: In the future, either (1) Multiple rules per form, or (2) Logic in your sidebar or backend to apply the correct tense/form dynamically

finglish_example: The course is designed especially for international students and job seekers who wish to know more about the characteristics of Finnish working life
corrected: The course is designed especially for international students and job seekers who wish to know more about what working in Finland is like.
sidebar: We don't say 'working life' in English. Consider 'working world', 'world of work', 'employment', 'professional' or something else instead.

finglish_example: Rapid HIV testing in a mobile unit in connection with Bear Picnic
corrected: Rapid HIV testing in a mobile unit at/during/in conjunction with Bear Picnic
sidebar: In English, 'in connection with' is usually used in news about crime. You probably mean 'at the same time or place as', so say that: 'at the event', 'during the event'. Alternatively, you can say 'in conjunction with'.

item: definite article, common noun, proper noun order
finglish_example: Accessibility at Learning Centre Aleksandria
corrected: Accessibility at the Aleksandria Learning Centre
sidebar: The pattern in English is (Proper Noun) (Common Noun) in names like the Clinton Presidential Library, the Aurora Learning Centre and the Wellcome Trust. If you put them the other way round ('Learning Centre Aurora'), you will sound unnatural.

finglish_example: The increase in number of passengers was visible especially in the North Atlantic and European routes; our customers are now booking holiday trips especially for their autumn leave and for the upcoming winter season; Covid vaccination coverage is improving swiftly especially in Asia
corrected: The increase in number of passengers was especially visible in the North Atlantic and European routes; our customers are now booking holiday trips, especially for their autumn leave and for the upcoming winter season; Covid vaccination coverage is improving swiftly, especially in Asia
sidebar: It often sounds unnatural to use 'especially' in the middle of a sentence without commas before or after the word. Consider putting a comma before 'especially' or rewriting the sentence with 'particularly'. So, not 'Prices are rising especially in Europe' but 'Prices are rising, particularly in Europe' or 'Prices in Europe are rising faster than elsewhere'. Not 'The increase was visible especially in the North American market' but 'The change was particularly visible in the North American market'.

finglish_example: Over its life cycle, SAF lowers carbon emissions drastically, even up to 80%, compared to fossil jet fuel.
corrected: Over its life cycle, SAF lowers carbon emissions drastically, by as much as 80%* compared to fossil jet fuel.
sidebar: The phrase in English is 'by as much as', not 'even up to'.

finglish_example: experience from five years
corrected: with five years of experience
sidebar: In English, we don't have expertise 'from' a period of time but 'spanning' or 'over': 'My experience spans two decades', 'She has experience with polymers over the past decade'.

finglish_example: You can apply for private daycare allowance from Kela
corrected: You can apply to Kela for private daycare allowance
sidebar: In English, you apply TO a bank, government department or organization for things like loans and social welfare benefits: 'We applied to the bank for a loan.'

finglish_example: The headless architecture was gone through especially thoroughly and different options discussed along the way
corrected: The headless architecture was gone over especially thoroughly and different options discussed along the way
sidebar: In English, we 'go through' physical things, like a park: 'I went through the park for a shortcut'. When you review something, you 'go over' it: 'We went over the contract once more'.

finglish_example: What to do, if we are not sure about the trustworthiness of external work force?
corrected: What to do if we are not sure about the trustworthiness of external work force?
sidebar: This comma may be incorrect. The rule in English is that the clause with 'if' ends with a comma. The other clause does not. Example: 'If you tried it, you'd love it'. But: 'You'd love it if you tried it'.

finglish_example: How is the sausage made
corrected: How is the sausage made? OR How the sausage is made
sidebar: This has the word order of a question, but there is no question mark at the end. Consider rewriting it or putting a question mark at the end. Not 'How is the sausage made' but 'How is the sausage made?' or 'How the sausage is made'.
notes: Flags likely questions missing question marks, not embedded clauses.

finglish_example: The programme is also taking place in several other countries such as Bolivia, Colombia, Tanzania, Uganda or Zambia!
corrected: The programme is also taking place in several other countries such as Bolivia, Colombia, Tanzania, Uganda and Zambia!
sidebar: Consider changing 'or' to 'and'. When you make a list in a regular, positive statement (not in a question), join the last two items with 'and', not 'or'. 'Or' is OK if you say something like 'you can choose eggs, ham or cheese'. However, we say 'eggs, ham and cheese are available'.

finglish_example: For us it was important not to paint ourselves in the corner when it comes to technologies and other choices; Finland's Jori Hulkkonen has never been the one to paint himself in the corner
corrected: For us it was important not to paint ourselves into a corner when it comes to technologies and other choices; Finland's Jori Hulkkonen has never been the one to paint himself into a corner
sidebar: The idiom in English is always in the form 'paint (reflexive pronoun) in a corner'. So: 'I painted myself in a corner.' 'Don't paint yourself in a corner!' 'She's painting herself in a corner.' A corner, not the corner, and 'into', not 'to'.

finglish_example: Gift cards are available at our following restaurants
corrected: Gift cards are available at the following restaurants; Gift cards are available at these restaurants in our chain; Buy gift cards here
sidebar: Following' is a determiner, not an adjective. That means you cannot use it with possessive pronouns like 'my' and 'our'. Instead of 'our following locations', say 'the following locations of ours'.

finglish_example: This course supports and prepares students studying abroad by providing them opportunities to practise
corrected: This course supports and prepares students studying abroad by providing them with opportunities to practise; This course supports and prepares students studying abroad by giving them opportunities to practise
sidebar: Say either 'provide (somebody) with (something)' or 'give (somebody) (something)'. Don't say 'provide (somebody) (something)'.
notes: Targets noun–noun structures after "provide" where "with" is missing.

finglish_example: SAF is a proven solution reducing GHG emissions by up to 80%
corrected: SAF is a proven solution which reduces GHG emissions by up to 80%; SAF is a proven solution, reducing GHG emissions by up to 80%; SAF is a proven solution for reducing GHG emissions by up to 80%
sidebar: This phrase is grammatically compressed in a way that feels awkward in English. Try adding a comma (“solution, reducing…”), or rephrase as “a solution that reduces” or “a solution for reducing”.

finglish_example: All journeys start from taking the first steps
corrected: All journeys start with taking the first steps; All journeys start with the first steps
sidebar: We say 'start from (a place)' but 'start with (an action)'. For example: 'I started from home' and 'she started by unpacking all the ingredients'.

finglish_example: A broad scoped design phase was key in getting all the different needs into the project and that the new service would cater as a basis for other countries’ and business areas’ ecommerce solutions
corrected: A broad scoped design phase was key in getting all the different needs into the project and in the new service catering as a basis for other countries’ and business areas’ ecommerce solutions
sidebar: This sentence mixes structures. After “in getting...”, it’s more natural to continue with “in...” + gerund (e.g. “in the service catering”), not “and that...”. Rephrase to match the structure: “in X and in Y” or “in X and Y-ing”.

finglish_example: every Myrsky employee knows that the greatest power is in the nature
corrected: every Myrsky employee knows that the greatest power is in nature
sidebar: When we say 'nature' to mean 'the natural world', we don’t use an article: 'Humans need to engage with nature'. When we say 'nature' to mean 'character', we use the article 'the': 'The nature of economics is complicated'.

finglish_example: Myrsky speaks honestly about processes taking place in the society
corrected: Myrsky speaks honestly about processes taking place in society
sidebar: When we mean 'human society in general', we don't say use an article: 'Changes in society over the years'. When we mean a particular society, we can use an article, but this is rare: 'The society I grew up in was very conservative'.

finglish_example: Mesensei designs and creates mobile solutions for organisations and companies. The company turned to Kodan when they wanted to renew their software development processes
corrected: Mesensei designs and creates mobile solutions for organisations and companies. The company turned to Kodan when it wanted to renew their software development processes
sidebar: We say 'it' rather than 'they' to refer to a company in English.

finglish_example: FCG’s Annual Review for the year 2022 is now available; The biggest individual projects in year 2022 were
corrected: FCG’s Annual Review for 2022 is now available; The biggest individual projects in 2022 were
sidebar: Only say 'the year NNNN' when it's at the start of a sentence to avoid starting the sentence with a numeral. In the middle or end of a sentence, you don't need to say 'the year'. You can just write the number.
Use decimal points to separate integers and decimals, not commas: 2.2, not 2,2. This also applies to all currencies: €25.23, not €25,23.

item: lack of comma before and after i.e.
finglish_example: The network business model is based on a broad network that is built around one or a few airports i.e. around the hub
corrected: The network business model is based on a broad network that is built around one or a few airports, i.e., around the hub
sidebar: Because i.e. means 'id est' or 'that is', you need to separate it from the rest of the sentence with a comma on either side.

item: excessively long abstract nouns over 15 characters and ending in -isation or -ization, such as operationalization, familiarization and more
finglish_example: The practical operationalization of the flood forecast and warning system includes awareness-raising and familiarization
corrected: When the flood forecast and warning system is launched in practice, we made people aware of and familiar with it.
sidebar: This abstract noun is too long. Make it more readable by saying what you actually did in plain language. So, not 'We increased familiarization with our strategy' but 'We presented our strategy' or 'We taught people about our strategy' or 'We made our strategy better-known to people'.

finglish_example: Many free-of-charge events in Helsinki on Independence Day
corrected: Many free events in Helsinki on Independence Day
sidebar: You don't need to say 'free of charge': you can just say 'free'!

finglish_example: Our mission is to keep our customers at the forefront of digital evolution by utilising our diverse expertise
corrected: Our mission is to keep our customers at the forefront of digital evolution by using our diverse expertise
sidebar: Utilize' and 'utilization' are redundant and too long. Just say 'use'. 'The use of the system.' 'We used the system.'

finglish_example: Already in the design phase we clearly recognized new needs; trainings played an important role already during the project
corrected: As early as in the design phase we clearly recognized new needs; trainings played an important role during the project
sidebar: “Already” is often unnecessary or awkward in English when used before time phrases. Try rewriting as “as early as”, “even during”, or omit “already” altogether.

finglish_example: We offer funding, advice, as well as information and contacts in the target market
corrected: We offer funding, advice, information and contacts in the target market
sidebar: As well as' is often unnecessary. Only use 'as well as' when the last item in your list is very distinct from the first items in your list. Otherwise, just use 'and'.

finglish_example: Case Seure; Case R-kioski; Case Marimekko
corrected: Testimonial: Seure; Customer success story: R-kioski; What we did for Marimekko
sidebar: English does not use 'case' like this, capitalized followed by a company name. Instead, consider 'Customer success story: Company Name'. Note the comma. Or rewrite the headline entirely: 'How we helped Company Name succeed'.
notes: You can always flag such longer phrases for manual review in your JSON by adding "manualReview": true.

finglish_example: It is customary to compliment the team spirit and smooth cooperation
corrected: It is customary to praise others’ team spirit and smooth cooperation
sidebar: We don't 'compliment' spirit or cooperation in English. Instead, we 'praise' it.

finglish_example: The measures of personnel satisfaction have gone in a better direction thanks to the cooperation
corrected: The measures of personnel satisfaction have gone in a better direction thanks to the service/consultation/Company Name
sidebar: Do you really mean cooperation, or do you mean a service your company provided to a client? If so, say that.

finglish_example: "We have achieved a lot as a team - teamwork is at the heart of our success,” enthuses Calvin; “The jury is not allowed to comment on anything during the competition, so the Shadow Jury can shed some light on issues that the jury might be pondering on”, clarifies soprano Olga Heikkilä; "We have, despite the pandemic, already built a solid foundation for it,” shares Pekka Mattila
corrected: "We have achieved a lot as a team - teamwork is at the heart of our success,” says Calvin; “The jury is not allowed to comment on anything during the competition, so the Shadow Jury can shed some light on issues that the jury might be pondering on”, says soprano Olga Heikkilä; "We have, despite the pandemic, already built a solid foundation for it,” says Pekka Mattila
sidebar: When you quote someone in English, these verbs are OK. Any other verbs sound strange: "say", "comment", "tell", "note", "begin", "conclude", "ask" or "answer".

finglish_example: Although the integration of these systems has not been fully completed at all levels, it does not prevent the launch of development work.
corrected: Although the integration of these systems has not been fully completed at all levels, it does not prevent improvements being made.
sidebar: What do you really mean by 'development work'? Can you rewrite it in a way that the reader instantly understands?

finglish_example: Due to long winters, Nordic people have become accustomed to spending a lot of time at home; If your degree studies at a Ukrainian higher education institution in the arts have been suspended due to the war in Ukraine
corrected: Long winters mean Nordic people spend a lot of time at home; If your degree studies at a Ukrainian higher education institution in the arts have been suspended because of the war in Ukraine
sidebar: Only say 'due to' when you mean something happening as a result of an unexpected but ultimately manageable interruption, like a strike or a power cut. Don't say something changes 'due to the war in Ukraine'. Use 'because' instead. And don't use 'due to' in marketing texts or sales copy. Say something more creative.

finglish_example: the service benefits insurers by providing them with high-quality leads and enabling them to focus on delivering optimal solutions
corrected: the service benefits insurers by providing them with high-quality leads and allowing them to focus on delivering optimal solutions
sidebar: Enable' means 'make possible', but what you might mean is 'allow', which means 'remove a barrier'.

finglish_example: Each work environment is an individual entity whose specific features should always be taken into account in safety training
corrected: Each work environment is unique: its specific features should always be taken into account in safety training
sidebar: We don't talk about 'entities' that often in English. Find a more natural way to say it, such as by saying the thing is unique or one of a kind.

finglish_example: Insta implements even the largest automation and digitalization projects with short lead times
corrected: Insta implements the largest automation and digitalization projects with short lead times
sidebar: Using 'even the' with a superlative (like 'biggest') sounds unnatural in English. You can just say the superlative. So not 'We paint even the largest office buildings' but 'We paint the largest office buildings' or 'We specialize in painting large office buildings of over 100,000 square metres'.

finglish_example: Wärtsilä’s new flagship is a forerunner in responsible energy and marine industry
corrected: Wärtsilä’s new flagship is a pioneer in responsible energy and marine industry
sidebar: In English, a 'forerunner' is an early example or version of something. You probably mean a 'pioneer' or 'industry leader'.

finglish_example: With professionally crafted and carefully personalized content, your business will attract more interest, gain appreciation, and pave the way to purchase decisions
corrected:
With professionally crafted and carefully personalized content, your business will attract more interest, gain clients’ appreciation, and pave the way to purchase decisions/
With professionally crafted and carefully personalized content, your business will attract more interest, become more respected in its field, and pave the way to purchase decisions
sidebar: Unless by 'gain appreciation' you mean 'increase in value', either say whose appreciation you've gained ('gain clients' appreciation) or say 'become more respected'.

finglish_example: Get to know our projects from last year in our Annual Review; Get to know our solutions
corrected: Read more about our projects from last year in our annual review/Explore our projects from last year in more detail in our annual review; Check out our solutions/Read about our solutions
sidebar: Get to know' is used when people get to know each other. Don't use it in a headline when you want your readers to learn more, read more or explore something. Use another verb.

finglish_example: Each project is unique, but we prefer working in 2-week sprints heeding the best practices of agile
corrected: Each project is unique, but we prefer working in 2-week sprints that apply the best practices of agile
sidebar: We don't 'heed' practices or models in English, we 'apply' them: 'Our company applies best practices'.

finglish_example: Our customer can rent a water treatment system for the needed time
corrected: Our customer can rent a water treatment system for the time needed/Our customer can rent a water treatment system for the necessary time
sidebar: The pattern in English is '(noun) needed' or 'necessary (noun)': 'You can rent the machine for the time needed' or 'You can rent the machine for the necessary time'.

finglish_example: Renewed online service rocketed visitor numbers to a huge rise
corrected: Renewed site/website rocketed visitor numbers to a huge rise
sidebar: We don't say 'online service' to mean a website in English. In English, 'online service' means the entire service a customer gets online, not a specific resource. Just say 'site' or 'website'.

finglish_example: A group of students participated in Hive Helsinki's Open Day
corrected: A group of students went to Hive Helsinki's Open Day
sidebar: Don't say "participate" with "event", "survey", "open day", or "conference". In English, we 'attend', 'go to' and 'be at' events, rather than 'participating in' them. For surveys, don't say 'participate': say 'answer', 'respond to' or 'take'.

finglish_example: By paying attention to accessibility and the responsiveness of the user interface we make sure that your digital service is usable anywhere
corrected: We focus sharply on the accessibility and the responsiveness of the user interface to make sure that your digital service is usable anywhere
sidebar: 'Pay attention to' is boring Finglish. Consider saying 'focus on', 'emphasize', 'prioritize' or something else instead.

finglish_example: one of the main reasons why my aunt had the possibility to do what she loved; I have also had a possibility to see comprehensively the progress of the telecommunications development
corrected: one of the main reasons why my aunt had the opportunity to do what she loved; I have also had the opportunity to see comprehensively the progress of the telecommunications development
sidebar: When you say 'possibility', it sounds like the thing never happened. You probably mean 'opportunity': 'I had the opportunity to do study abroad' ('I studied abroad'). By contrast, if you say 'I had the possibility to study abroad', it doesn't necessarily mean you studied abroad.

finglish_example: references
corrected: projects/case studies/customer success stories/past clients
sidebar: If you mean clients you've served or projects you've done in the past, don't say 'references', because we don't use the word that way in English.

finglish_example: We renewed our long-haul cabins
corrected: We overhauled/modernized/updated our long-haul cabins
sidebar: In English, we 'renew' driving licences, wedding vows and insurance policies. When you make something 'like new', you 'modernize', 'overhaul' or 'update' it.

finglish_example: We sparred with Sowellus over user experience design
corrected: Sowellus was our sparring partner for user experience design; We bounced some ideas around with Sowellus about user experience design; We used Sowellus as a sounding board for user experience design.
sidebar: When you 'spar' with someone in English, you have a fight with them. What you probably mean is 'use as a sparring partner', 'bounce ideas around with' or 'use as a sounding board'.

finglish_example: Software developer Aki Panuma’s career at Probot started with project periods during his studies
corrected: Software developer Aki Panuma’s career at Probot started with project periods while at university
sidebar: This is not incorrect English: it just sounds a little unnatural. We don't say 'during my studies'; we say 'while I was at college/university' or 'during my degree'.
notes: Would you like help testing whether your click-and-replace logic supports dynamic capture groups like \1?

finglish_example: We also take care of the reliability of your information systems
corrected: We also ensure the reliability of your information systems
sidebar: In English, we 'take care of' a sick person, a plant or an animal. When you want someone to be well, you say 'take care'. If you are a business offering a service, you don't 'take care of your customer's security', you 'provide security' or 'ensure security'.

finglish_example: We felt that the cybersecurity team, in particular, needed tough experts, as there was no room to compromise here
corrected: We felt that the cybersecurity team, in particular, needed seasoned/experienced/skilled experts, as there was no room to compromise here
sidebar: We don't use 'tough' with 'expert' in English. Say 'experienced', 'formidable', 'skilled' or something else instead.

finglish_example: The system makes it possible to see in real time how traffic runs and whether the various partners are sticking to their service obligations
corrected: The system makes it possible to see in real time how the trams/vehicles/trains are running and whether the various partners are sticking to their service obligations
sidebar: In English, 'traffic' isn't the cars, vehicles, trams or trains on a road or track – it's 'congestion'. What you might mean is 'transport' or 'vehicles'.

finglish_example: It makes no sense using money for boring souvenirs
corrected: It makes no sense spending money on boring souvenirs
sidebar: In English, we don't "use money for" things, we 'spend money on' things.

finglish_example: please see our agent at the airport Arrival Service desk to verify the damage and create a damage report
corrected: please see our agent at the airport Arrival Service desk so they can verify the damage and create a damage report
sidebar: Verify' means 'see for yourself that it is true'. If you mean 'prove something to someone else', say that, or use another verb.

finglish_example: Contact our Customer Service at Messages and tell them that you want to combine your household’s insurance policies into a single whole
corrected: Contact our Customer Service at Messages and tell them that you want to consolidate all your household’s insurance policies into one policy
sidebar: We don't use the word 'whole' as a noun that often in English. Just repeat the noun that you're referring to. For example, if you're talking about insurance, say 'we can combine all of your insurance policies into one policy' (NOT 'into a single whole').

finglish_example: Works; Our Works
corrected: Our work; Projects; Customer success stories; Testimonials
sidebar: Works' in English, as a noun, means a large factory (or miracles performed by Jesus and the saints). When you say 'Works' our 'Our works' as a headline, not everyone will understand you. Consider instead: 'What we do', 'Services', 'Our strengths', 'Past projects' or something similar.

item: comma + and joining sentences without subject
finglish_example: The importance of automation and data utilisation in business is growing, and intelligent business is the next level of digitalisation.
corrected: The importance of automation and data utilisation in business is growing. Intelligent business is the next level of digitalisation.
sidebar: Make your text easier to read. Split long sentences into two or more. A comma and 'and', like here, is probably a sign you need to split the sentence up.
notes: Designed to catch when 'and' introduces a clause missing a subject.

finglish_example: Automation was implemented using rotary indexing table
corrected: Automation was done using rotary indexing table
sidebar: Implement' is too long. Use a verb like 'do', 'run' or 'conduct' instead. It will make your text easier to read.

finglish_example: Check out the Kojamo Sustainability programme in the form of a podcast
corrected: Check out the Kojamo Sustainability programme podcast
sidebar: Do you really need 'in the form of'? Can you delete it? For example: NOT 'we published our ideas in the form of a book' but instead 'we published our ideas in a book' or 'as a book'.

finglish_example: clear guidelines on the future of the company and the intentions of its owners
corrected: clear guidelines on the company’s future and its owners’ intentions
sidebar: If you are talking about people or groups of people (such as companies), use apostrophe + S rather than 'of'. So instead of 'the intention of the owners', say 'the owners' intentions'. Instead of 'the management of the company', say 'the company's management' (or 'the company management').

item: passive when there is a subject
finglish_example: Visas are issued by Finnish diplomatic missions abroad.
corrected: Finnish diplomatic missions abroad issue visas.
sidebar: If you know who does the action, say it. Not 'Visas are issued by Finnish embassies abroad' but 'Finnish embassies abroad issue visas'.
notes: Would you like me to help you build a data model for this kind of dynamic sentence transformation inside your JSON or UI logic?

finglish_example: Basics of Open and Responsible Science is aimed at UEF and YUFE network graduate students, but the course material is usable to everyone
corrected: Basics of Open and Responsible Science is aimed at UEF and YUFE network graduate students, but everyone can use the course material
sidebar: This is technically correct, but may sound unnatural. Instead of saying 'the material is usable to everyone', say 'everyone can use the material' or 'the material is available to everyone'.

finglish_example: As part of Turku University Hospital, Auria Biobank, is, among other things, a repository of over 1M+ tissue samples from patients
corrected: As part of Turku University Hospital, Auria Biobank is a repository of over 1M+ tissue samples from patients
sidebar: Nobody cares whether the thing is one of many other things! It's probably completely irrelevant, so just leave it out.

finglish_example: Is it possible that fares will fall
corrected: Could/Can fares fall
sidebar: We have a modal in English, 'can'/'could'. We don't need to say 'Is it possible that things could change?' We can just say 'Can things change?' or 'Could things change?' Keep it simple and readable!

finglish_example: Myrsky’s task is to produce domestic renewable energy to strengthen local vitality, improve Finland’s self-sufficiency and support the green transition. Työmaa consequently started to refine an idea of a continuously renewing company with the environment as one of its most important partners.
corrected: Myrsky’s task is to produce domestic renewable energy to strengthen local vitality, improve Finland’s self-sufficiency and support the green transition. That is why Työmaa started to refine an idea of a continuously renewing company with the environment as one of its most important partners.
sidebar: Consequently' is too long. Either say 'that is why' or say nothing at all. It's often obvious that something is a consequence of something else.

finglish_example: Learn more about different sustainable palm oil options; This tool allowed us to unify and replace several separate tools and speed up the different work stages of energy system and energy consumption calculations
corrected: Learn more about sustainable palm oil options; This tool allowed us to unify and replace several separate tools and speed up the work stages of energy system and energy consumption calculations
sidebar: You don't need to say 'different stages' or 'different options'. It's often clear from context that they are distinct, different stages or options. So, not 'Explore the different treatment options' but 'Explore the treatment options'. Not 'Track the different stages of assembly' but 'Track the stages of assembly'.

finglish_example: We offer diverse opportunities for continuous improvement of your professional competence, in line with your own goals
corrected: We offer extensive opportunities for continuous improvement of your professional competence, in line with your own goals
sidebar: Diverse' is used for people, not things. So if you are not talking about humans here, say 'extensive', 'a range of', or consider leaving it out altogether.

finglish_example: We provide e.g. the following services for faculty and staff
corrected: For example, we provide the following services for faculty and staff
sidebar: We don't use the abbreviation e.g. like this in the middle of a sentence in English. E.g. is for legal contracts and other technical documentation, not text you intend people to read willingly. Say 'for example' instead. Or don't say it: it might be clear that what you're saying is an example, so even 'for example' might be unnecessary.

finglish_example: The error situation in the online store has been corrected
corrected: The error in the online store has been corrected
sidebar: You don't need to say 'error situation'. You can just say 'error'. Your reader will know it was a situation.

finglish_example: “We have achieved a lot,” enthused Calvin
corrected: “We have achieved a lot,” said Calvin
sidebar: When you quote someone in English, these verbs are OK. Any other verbs sound strange: "say", "comment", "tell", "note", "begin", "conclude", "ask" or "answer".
notes: Verbs like “shared”, “clarified”, “enthused” are odd in this position.

finglish_example: We support your career development. For example, we offer learning programmes for juniors, have lots of internal trainings, and all our employees become certified business technology professionals.
corrected: We support your career development. We offer learning programmes for juniors, have lots of internal trainings, and all our employees become certified business technology professionals.
sidebar: Only say “for example” if you’re giving just one or two examples. If you’re listing everything, skip it.

finglish_example: We created a web app called Oma Puhti, where people can check their test results and if needed, contact a doctor.
corrected: We created a web app called Oma Puhti, where people can check their test results and contact a doctor.
sidebar: Do you want to sell to people or not? 'If needed, you can buy spare parts from us' sounds like you don't want to sell. 'You can buy spare parts from us' or 'Buy spare parts from us' sounds much better.

finglish_example: Yes, it can. If you wish, you can use the gift card to pay part of the total amount of your purchase.
corrected: Yes, it can. You can use the gift card to pay part of the total amount of your purchase.
sidebar: If you say can, why would you say 'if you wish'? It sounds like you don't want the person to do it. Not 'if you wish, you can use the gift card in our store' but 'you can use the gift card in our store'.

finglish_example: In addition to placing orders via our online service, you can also do so via the traditional channels
corrected: In addition to placing orders via our online service, you can do so via the traditional channels
sidebar: In addition to' and 'also' mean the same thing. You don't need both. Only say one or the other.

finglish_example: Seven Finnish municipalities are building a platform that will bring together information, systems and services for comprehensive and upper secondary school students, teachers, parents and administrators in the future. In practice, the platform makes life easier for and frees up time for teaching and student support.
corrected: Seven Finnish municipalities are building a platform that will bring together information, systems and services for comprehensive and upper secondary school students, teachers, parents and administrators in the future. The platform makes life easier for and frees up time for teaching and student support.
sidebar: Do you really need 'in practice' or does your sentence make it obvious? Consider: 'In practice, the bridge connects the mainland to the island.' Of course it does! Why not just say 'The bridge connects the mainland to the island'?

finglish_example: Plan projects in such a way that they are sensible, profitable, and sustainable
corrected: Plan projects so they are sensible, profitable, and sustainable; Plan projects to be sensible, profitable and sensible
sidebar: In such a way that' is five words where one will do: 'so'. Or, you can rewrite the sentence: 'Plan projects in such a way that they succeed' – 'Plan projects to succeed'.

finglish_example: I work at Codento, a consulting company specializing in cloud technology, software development, and data/AI topics, and my job description includes, among other things, finding the right talent for our clients.
corrected: I work at Codento, a consulting company specializing in cloud technology, software development, and data/AI topics, and my job description includes finding the right talent for our clients.
sidebar: Includes' means 'this list is non-exhaustive'. You don't need to say 'includes, among other things'. If it's a legal contract, you can perhaps write 'including, but not limited to'. But only in a legal contract.

finglish_example: Fortum’s smart electricity contracts and additional services bring predictability and ease to your home’s electricity matters.; You can take care of your insurance and claims matters quickly and easily via phone.
corrected: Fortum’s smart electricity contracts and additional services bring predictability and ease to your home’s electricity.; You can take care of your insurance and claims quickly and easily via phone.
sidebar: You don't need to say 'matters'. You can just say what the 'matters' are. Not 'call us about your insurance matters' but 'call us about your insurance'.

finglish_example: What made the case special was that all technology and other choices were made keeping in mind Paulig’s broader ecommerce business
corrected: What made the case special was that all technology and other choices were made with Paulig’s broader ecommerce business in mind
pattern: \b(was|were|is|are|had been|has been|have been|will be|would be|being|been|made|chosen|selected|designed)\s+keeping in mind\b
sidebar: In English, “keeping in mind…” works best with active voice. For passive constructions, use “with X in mind” instead. For example: “…choices were made with Paulig’s ecommerce business in mind.”

finglish_example: The reduced number of packing parts also reduces the number of storage places required
corrected: Fewer packing parts also means fewer storage places required
sidebar: We have a word in English, 'fewer'. We don't need to say 'reduced number'.

item: simultaneously, at the same time at the start of a sentence
finglish_example: Regardless of the channel, your company can produce a whole and targeted customer experience. Simultaneously, more efficient customer information management enables additional sales.
corrected: Regardless of the channel, your company can produce a whole and targeted customer experience. More efficient customer information management enables additional sales.
sidebar: It's often clear from context that the two things happened at the same time. Only use 'simultaneously' or 'at the same time' if you are sure the contrast is strong enough.

finglish_example: More information about the possible uses of AI in Finnish health care will soon be available when the survey work done by the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health
corrected: More information about the possible uses of AI in Finnish health care will soon be available when the survey/study/questionnaire done by the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health
sidebar: You don't need to call every type of work 'work'. Just say 'survey', 'questionnaire' or 'investigation'.

finglish_example: Together with our partners, we are on a journey toward an emission-free energy system
corrected: With our partners, we are on a journey toward an emission-free energy system
sidebar: With' works by itself. You don't need to say 'together with'. It's too many words.

finglish_example: We offer versatile services for private customers, such as daily banking, loans, savings and investments, as well as extensive owner-customer benefits
corrected: We offer a wide range of services for private customers, such as daily banking, loans, savings and investments, as well as extensive owner-customer benefits
sidebar: Versatile' usually means a person's physical versatility, their ability to bend and stretch. So if you are not talking about humans here, say 'extensive', 'a range of', or consider leaving it out altogether.

finglish_example: Your rights with regard to the processing of personal data
corrected: Your personal data processing rights
sidebar: With regard to' is too many words. Instead of 'your rights with regard to personal data processing', say 'your personal data processing rights'.

finglish_example: Metso is a frontrunner in sustainable technologies
corrected: Metso is an industry leader in sustainable technologies
sidebar: In English, a 'frontrunner' is someone who runs ahead. You probably mean a 'pioneer' or 'industry leader'.

finglish_example: We Value Your Feedback – Participate in Our Survey
corrected: We Value Your Feedback – Respond to Our Survey
replacement: respond to the survey|answer the survey
sidebar: Don't say "participate" with "event", "survey", "open day", or "conference". In English, we 'attend', 'go to' and 'be at' events, rather than 'participating in' them. For surveys, don't say 'participate': say 'answer', 'respond to' or 'take'.

finglish_example: We are participating in the event; we participated in the conference
corrected: We are attending the event; we attended the conference
sidebar: Don't say "participate" with "event", "survey", "open day", or "conference". In English, we 'attend', 'go to' and 'be at' events, rather than 'participating in' them. For surveys, don't say 'participate': say 'answer', 'respond to' or 'take'.

finglish_example: A three-mile designated off-road cycling trail also is offered
corrected: A three-mile designated off-road cycling trail is also offered
sidebar: Place 'also' before the verb 'be': 'The grass is green. It is also delicious to cows.' 'Extended financing is also offered.'

finglish_example: However, in especially master level studies in most fields, the student should be a student in that specific field in order to take the courses.
corrected: However, particularly in master level studies in most fields, the student should be a student in that specific field in order to take the courses.
sidebar: Especially' sounds unnatural between the 'in' and the noun. Not 'In especially master's studies, the student should be prepared' but 'Particularly in master's studies, the student should be prepared'.

finglish_example: How does Neste refine fuels
corrected: How Neste refines fuels
sidebar: This has the word order of a question, but there is no question mark at the end. Consider rewriting it or putting a question mark at the end. Not 'How could we improve' but 'How could we improve?' or 'How  we could improve'.
notes: incorporate second step to ensure question mark replaces any trailing full stop

finglish_example: How could Neste work smarter
corrected: How Neste could work smarter
sidebar: This has the word order of a question, but there is no question mark at the end. Consider rewriting it or putting a question mark at the end. Not 'How does the cookies crumble' but 'How does the cookie crumble?' or 'How the cookie crumbles'.
notes: incorporate second step to ensure question mark replaces any trailing full stop

finglish_example: What Lamia brought to the table already early in the process was the headless approach
corrected: What Lamia brought to the table early in the process was the headless approach;
sidebar: “Already” is often unnecessary or awkward in English when used before time phrases. Try rewriting as “as early as”, “even during”, or omit “already” altogether.

finglish_example: We help our customers to improve their own recycling rate by means of planned origin sorting, we take care of the collection of materials with collection solutions that promote sorting, and we deliver the materials for further processing into recycled raw materials for industry.
corrected: We help our customers recycle more through planned origin sorting. We take collect waste at source using solutions that promote sorting. We transport the materials for further processing into recycled raw materials for industry.
sidebar: This sentence is really long, with over 25 words. Consider cutting it into two or more sentences.
